#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Sydney
#Text=Sydney is the Harbour City .
#Text=It is the largest , oldest and most cosmopolitan city in Australia with an enviable reputation as one of the world 's most beautiful and liveable cities .
#Text=Brimming with history , nature , culture , art , fashion , cuisine and design , it is set next to miles of ocean coastline and sandy surf beaches .
#Text=The city is also home to the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge , two of the most iconic structures on the planet .
#Text=Sydney is a major global city and an important finance centre in the Asia-Pacific region .
#Text=The city is surrounded by nature and national parks , which extend through the suburbs and right to the shores of the harbour .
#Text=Districts
#Text=Sydney has a compact city core surrounded by sprawling suburbs , forming a vast metropolitan area .

#Text=The city core , Central Sydney is shaped roughly like a stubby palm-up left hand : the heel of the thumb as City South , the thumb as the district Darling Harbour , the first finger as The Rocks , the palm with the second and third fingers as City Centre and the rest as City East .
#Text=Greater Sydney
#Text=Greater Sydney , the sprawling suburbs in the vast city metropolitan area surrounding Central Sydney spread for up to 100 km westward from the city centre .
#Text=The traveller visiting the suburbs will find less crowded beaches , parks , cheaper shopping , commercial centres , cultural festivals and hidden gems .
#Text=History
#Text=Sydney is the oldest European settlement in Australia , having been founded as a British penal colony on 26 January 1788 by Arthur Phillip .

#Text=This day is now celebrated as Australia Day to mark the establishment of a new nation , although also regarded by many as Invasion Day that marked the beginning of the British appropriation of Aboriginal land .
#Text=The settlement was named " Sydney " after Thomas Townshend , 1st Viscount Sydney , who was the British Home Secretary at that time .
#Text=People
#Text=Sydney is one of the most cosmopolitan cities on the planet , with one third of its population born overseas .
#Text=European settlement rapidly displaced the Aboriginal people of the Sydney area with colonists largely coming from England , Ireland and Scotland .
#Text=The Australian goldrush attracted more immigrants , including a significant number of Chinese , with about one in six Australians with convict descent also having some Chinese ancestry .

#Text=In the early 20th century , Sydney continued to attract immigrants - mostly from the UK and Ireland , with the White Australia Policy preventing non-European peoples ( and even Southern Europeans ) from settling .

#Text=Australia 's immigration patterns , and consequently , that of Sydney , changed significantly after World War II , when migrants began to arrive from countries as diverse as Italy , Greece , Germany , Holland , China , New Zealand , India , the Philippines , Poland , Lebanon , Iraq , Vietnam , Thailand , South Africa and the Pacific Islands .
#Text=Sydney 's culture , food and general outlook well reflect these contributions to the majority Anglo-Celtic institutions and social establishment .
#Text=Sydney is recognised worldwide for its vibrant LGBT community .
#Text=Every year , the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras is celebrated on the first weekend in March , drawing people from all over Australia and the world for the celebrations .

#Text=Sydney was the centre of the world 's attention in September 2000 when the city hosted the Summer Olympics - announced by the IOC Chairman at the closing ceremony to be " the best games ever " .
#Text=The Olympics saw a major building and renovation program take hold of Sydney , positioning it as one of the great world cities of the 21st century .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Sydney enjoys over 300 sunny days each year , and it 's a year-round destination .
#Text=Avoid the hottest days for energetic outside activities , and avoid the coolest if you 're planning a beach holiday .
#Text=Summer ( December to February ) is the best time to enjoy Sydney 's beachside outdoor lifestyle .

#Text=Temperatures usually reach around 26°C ( about 79°F ) but it can be very hot , particularly further inland and to the west , with temperatures climbing to over 40°C ( 104°F ) for a few days each summer .

#Text=Summer days can be humid , and sometimes have searing dry winds , but hot days frequently end with a " southerly buster " , a cold front sweeping up from the south , bringing a clearly noticeable drop in temperature , as well as rain and thunder .
#Text=Within hours , the storm can pass and the evening continues cooler .
#Text=Hot , windy days can create a risk of bushfire , and on days of severe risk national parks and walking trails may be closed .
#Text=Occasionally low pressure systems drift down from the tropics , giving periods of more unstable weather .
#Text=You wo n't need to pack much more than T-shirts to visit Sydney in summer , but remember your hat and sunglasses .
#Text=Autumn ( March to May ) is still warm with mild nights .
#Text=There can be good days for the beach in March , but you ca n't count on it .
#Text=It is a good time for visiting attractions , going to the zoo , catching ferries around the harbour without the summer crowds .
#Text=You may need a warm top for the evenings , especially for May .
#Text=Winter ( June to August ) is cool , not cold .
#Text=Average July maximum temperatures are 17°C , and daytime temperatures rarely drop below 14°C , but night-time temperatures can fall to below 10°C .
#Text=Most rain falls as a result of a few off-shore low pressure systems , which usually result in two or three rainy weeks during winter .
#Text=The Bondi Icebergs will be in the ocean doing their morning laps , but most of Sydney will be well away from the beach .
#Text=It does not snow in Sydney , and unless you intend spending long periods outside , you can usually get by with just a warm top .
#Text=Sydney is a year-round city , and only the outdoor water-parks close for the winter .
#Text=If the beach is n't your scene , and you do n't like the heat , winter may be your time to visit .
#Text=Spring ( September to November ) .
#Text=Spring days are great for exploring Sydney 's attractions , bushwalking , cycling , and the outdoors .
#Text=Beaches are generally patrolled from the end of October , and Sydneysiders start flocking to the beaches in November .
#Text=Sydney 's Western Suburbs , which lie away from the coast , tend to be hotter during the day , colder during the night and not receiving as much rain .
#Text=They miss the afternoon sea breezes and the night-time warming effect of the ocean .
#Text=Most public buildings like shopping centres are climate controlled inside .
#Text=Sydney has a fascination with year-round alfresco dining , where you can find yourself dining mid-winter outdoors with a heater a few tables away .
#Text=Around 90 % of public transport has heating and cooling .
#Text=For the other 10 % climate control consists of an open window .
#Text=Carry water on a hot day .
#Text=Sydney climate and weather information is available online at the Australian Bureau of Meteorology .
